page.title: Negative Constructions
page.introduction:
All languages have the ability to express negation. This is usually achieved through the use of:
special negative degree words, such as not, or negative quantifier determiners, such as no, which negate a nominal phrase,
negative indefinite pronouns, such as noboby or nothing, which express a negative nominal argument by themselves,
negative adverbs, such as never or nowhere,
negative auxiliaries, such as not or the contraction affixal form -n’t, and/or
negative verbal affixes.
All of the above have been covered as individual items in previous sections. This section will review the information you have given and obtain examples used in complete sentences, beginning with negation of nominal phrases where the negated phrase is the subject. We are interested here in how your language expresses sentences such as:

EnglishExample.exItem: Not all the children came to the party.
No more students can enroll in the class.
Nobody gave Mary a Valentine card.

page.introduction: The next section does the same for negative adverbial and auxiliary elements. The final page then deals with any co-occurrence restrictions between the various items when they are used together in full sentences containing a negated object, based upon the type of negation system your language uses.
